hypotheses: H1: Fraud increases with violence up to a point and then declines (inverted U-shape).
H2: Incumbent fraud does not exhibit spatial displacement.
H3: Contender fraud exhibits spatial displacement: local violence negatively correlates with fraud while nearby violence positively correlates with fraud.

claim.statement: There is an inverted U-shaped relationship between violence and election fraud, driven by the operation and displacement of candidates' loyalty networks.

data.source: Multiple sources including declassified geocoded military reports (insurgent event data), polling-station level election returns, Electoral Complaints Commission (ECC) recount/audit data (randomly sampled ballot boxes), WITS dataset for event locations, 2007 NRVA household survey, GTOPO30, and LandScan population estimates.
data.wave_or_subset: 2009 Afghanistan presidential election (district- and polling-station-level analyses); recount sample of 342 randomly selected ballot boxes; district-level measures across Afghanistan's 398 districts with analysis samples varying by model (e.g., N≈375, N≈363).
data.sample_size: Measures applied to 398 districts in Afghanistan; regression sample sizes reported in models vary (example: N=375 for Model 5; N=363 for Model 6). Recount sample: 342 ballot boxes; polling-center sample sizes referenced (e.g., 471 polling centers for 2010 election context) in descriptive material.
data.unit_of_analysis: Primary unit: district (district-level analysis). Additional analyses at the polling-station/ballot-box level for forensic/recount validation.
data.access_details: Not stated (data sources described but specific access procedures or links not provided in the paper summary).
data.notes: Uses a mix of fine-grained geocoded event data and district-aggregated election returns. Forensic fraud measure based on Beber–Scacco last-digit test and ECC recount-based indicators. Some variation in sample sizes across models due to missing data/closed stations; district-level last-digit tests and recount aggregation involve potential Type I/II error considerations discussed by authors.

method.description: The study develops a theoretical model predicting an inverted U-shaped relationship between violence and local election fraud driven by candidates' loyalty networks. Empirically, it uses district- and polling-station-level election returns, applies a last-digit forensic test (Beber–Scacco) to detect suspicious vote-count patterns, validates forensic measures with a recount/audit of randomly sampled ballot boxes (ECC recount), and links fraud measures to fine-grained geocoded violence/event data. Regression analyses (OLS and logit variants) with controls and spatial specifications test the inverted U-shape and differential spatial displacement for incumbent versus contender fraud.
steps: Assemble datasets: polling-station level returns, ECC recount/audit of ballot boxes, geocoded insurgent event data, household survey covariates (NRVA), geographic and population data (GTOPO30, LandScan), and other district covariates.
Aggregate polling-station results to district level where appropriate and compute forensic fraud indicators using the Beber–Scacco last-digit test (chi-square tests of last-digit uniformity).

Use ECC recount/audit of 342 randomly selected ballot boxes to construct recount-based fraud ratios and validate the last-digit forensic measure (compare significance of last-digit tests to share of manipulated boxes).
Construct violence measures for districts (violence at election time and in adjacent districts) using geocoded event data; compute squared violence term to test non-linearity (inverted U-shape).

Estimate regression models (OLS and logit) predicting district-level fraud measures from violence measures, violence-squared, spatial violence (adjacent districts), and control variables (e.g., number of closed stations, electrification, per-capita expenditure, distance from Kabul, elevation).
Estimate candidate-specific models to compare incumbent (Karzai) versus contender (Abdullah) fraud patterns and test spatial displacement hypotheses.
Conduct robustness checks and discuss limitations (e.g., potential biases in violence measures, limitations of digit-based tests, lack of exogenous variation to claim causality).
method.models: Forensic chi-square last-digit tests (Beber–Scacco) at polling-station/district level; OLS and logit regression models predicting district-level fraud measures; spatial specifications including violence in adjacent districts and quadratic terms (violence and violence-squared) to test inverted U-shape.
method.outcome_variable: District-level fraud measures: significance measure (p-value) from last-digit test; recollect/recount-based fraud ratio (share of audited boxes flagged as manipulated); candidate-specific fraud measures (fraud for Karzai and for Abdullah).
method.independent_variables: Primary: measures of insurgent violence during the election period (district-level violence), squared violence term (to test non-linearity/inverted U), violence in adjacent districts (spatial displacement).
method.control_variables: Number of closed stations, district electrification rate, per-capita household expenditure (NRVA), distance from Kabul, district elevation, population measures (LandScan) and other district-level covariates included in regressions.
method.tools_software: Not stated (no explicit mentions of software packages or codebase in the summary).

results.summary: The study finds empirical support for the theoretical prediction of an inverted U-shaped relationship between violence and election fraud: fraud rises with violence up to a point and then declines in high-violence districts where loyalty-network operations are disrupted. Validation of the last-digit forensic measure with ECC recount data shows a positive correlation between last-digit test significance and recount-based evidence of manipulated ballot boxes. Candidate-specific analyses indicate differing patterns: the incumbent's fraud network is relatively embedded in the electoral apparatus and less spatially displaced, while the contender's fraud efforts show spatial displacement (negative correlation with local violence and positive correlation with nearby violence). The authors note limitations regarding causality and generalizability beyond contexts where violence is not biased toward a particular candidate.
